results.firPara: From Steve Morrow falling from Tony Adamss shoulders to Stuart McCall headbutting an affordable car, here are half-a-dozen bittersweet moments
results.secPara: From Steve Morrow falling from Tony Adamss shoulders to Stuart McCall headbutting an affordable car, here are half-a-dozen bittersweet moments
results.webTitle: The Joy of Six: football celebrations gone wrong | Michael Butler

results.firPara: Chris Coleman has insisted his decision to give Ben Woodburn a first senior call-up at the age of 17 has nothing to do with trying to commit the Liverpool striker to playing for Wales rather than England.
results.secPara: Woodburn, who wrote his name into Liverpools record books in November when he became the clubs youngest goalscorer, is eligible to play for England and Wales. He was born in Nottingham and has been the subject of interest from England in the past but also qualifies for Wales through his maternal grandfather.
results.webTitle: Chris Coleman denies trying to tie wonderkid Ben Woodburn to Wales

results.firPara: Middlesbrough seem set to appoint an interim successor to Aitor Karanka before making a longer-term appointment in the summer, with the job apparently Steve Agnews to lose.
results.secPara: An amalgam of excessive tactical caution and questionable man-management prompted Karankas sacking on Thursday, leaving Agnew, his assistant, in charge for Sundays game at home to Manchester United.
results.webTitle: Middlesbrough ask Steve Agnew to take charge after sacking Aitor Karanka

results.firPara: Todays rumours are snuffling for truffles
results.secPara: Todays rumours are snuffling for truffles
results.webTitle: Football transfer rumours: Liverpool to pounce for Timo Werner?

results.firPara: Romelu Lukaku has questioned whether Everton share his ambitions to win trophies and play Champions League football after informing the club this week that he has no desire to sign a new contract at Goodison Park.
results.secPara: Everton offered Lukaku fresh terms and a new five-year deal but the Belgium striker has rejected the deal that would have made him the best-paid player in the clubs history.
results.webTitle: Romelu Lukaku questions Everton’s ambitions to ‘win big trophies’

results.firPara: • Manchester United forward was initially expected to drop down to under-21s
results.secPara: Gareth Southgates diminished options for the centre-forward places in his first England squad since being confirmed as manager have led to a change of heart behind the scenes about the role Marcus Rashford ought to play in the coming weeks.
results.webTitle: England’s Gareth Southgate looks to Marcus Rashford as injury list lengthens

results.firPara: Samir Nasri has branded Jamie Vardy a cheat and accused the Leicester City striker of getting him sent off by playacting during the second half of Sevillas Champions League last-16 defeat at the King Power Stadium on Tuesday night.
results.secPara: Sevilla were trailing 2-0 and Nasri was on a booking when he squared up to Vardy, who stumbled backwards after the two went forehead to forehead, with the Frenchman later claiming that he made no contact with the England international. He didnt say anything but he played it well, Nasri said.
results.webTitle: Samir Nasri tells Jamie Vardy to ‘play the game like a man’ after red card

results.firPara: There were 22 minutes left when Julian Brandt ran through again, one on one with Jan Oblak. The shot went slightly to his left but Atlético Madrids goalkeeper stopped it. The ball ran free to Kevin Volland but Oblak stopped it again, full stretch now, only for it to run free to Kevin Volland for a second time.
results.secPara: Eight yards out, he hit towards goal but, somehow, Oblak was there again, scrambling to his feet and flying across, his third save more astonishing than the previous two. Again it dropped and this time Javier Hernández shot wide. The Calderón erupted and burst into song Obi, Oblak, every day I love you more.
results.webTitle: Atlético go through motions against Bayer Leverkusen to reach last eight

results.firPara: Manchester City crashed out of the Champions League last 16 to a spirited and talented Monaco on away goals
results.secPara: Thats that! City simply gave themselves too much to do after a terrible first-half display! And so last years semi-finalists have failed to make it through the Round of 16. Pep Guardiolas 100th match in European competition ends in failure; its the first time hes crashed out at this stage of the Champions League. City had chances to get themselves out of trouble in that second half, but passed too many up. For six minutes, it looked like Leroy Sane had saved them, but Tiemoue Bakayokos header put Monaco through. On balance, the French league leaders deserve to scrape through this high-scoring tie on away goals; they were always effervescent in attack, and tonights first half was the one big difference in an otherwise tight ding-dong battle over two legs. Citys long wait for their first European Cup - their journey started back in 1968 - goes on. Monaco are a step closer to their second final. And Leicester City are the Premier Leagues sole representatives in the quarter finals. Hey, they are the champions of England, after all.
results.webTitle: Monaco 3-1 Manchester City (agg 6-6): Champions League last 16, second leg – as it happened

results.firPara: Pep Guardiola marched across the turf at the end with head bowed and a face like thunder, barely making eye contact with his players or daring to glance up at the anguished away support behind the far goal. This was everything he had feared it might become, a chastening evening when hope flared only fleetingly and, in truth, his team had merited their mauling. Monaco are one of the more thrilling young sides in Europe but City, semi-finalists last year, and their manager, had expected far better than this.
results.secPara: It was the feeble nature of their first-half showing which left Guardiola seething, a display utterly lacking in snap and bite, cohesion and even conviction. Elimination on away goals gives the impression this tie was tight, and there was anxiety for the home side to endure in the last quarter for all that City effectively held the ascendancy for only six minutes. But the memory that will linger of these two matches will not be that rat-a-tat of goals in the last 20 minutes at the Etihad but the manner in which the visitors were overwhelmed in the opening period of the return. That is what shocked Guardiola to his core. He is not used to seeing his own outclassed, even bullied.
results.webTitle: Monaco’s Tiemoué Bakayoko condemns Manchester City to away-goal defeat
